transcript:
Patient: I think a more realistic standard would be to acknowledge that I'm doing my best, even if it's not perfect. And to recognize that my worth as a person isn't solely defined by my role as a mother. I'm also a student, a friend, a member of my community... I contribute in many ways.

Therapist: That's a really important insight, Maria. Recognizing that your worth is multi-faceted and not solely tied to one role is a significant step in developing a more balanced and compassionate view of yourself. It's also important to acknowledge, as you said, that you're doing your best, even if it's not perfect. Perfection is an unrealistic and unattainable standard, and holding ourselves to it only leads to feelings of inadequacy and self-criticism.

Let's try to apply this new perspective to the situation with your divorce and your children. I know you've been struggling with feelings of guilt and shame, believing that you failed as a mother during that time. How might this new, more compassionate standard change how you view that situation?

Patient: I guess, looking back, I can see that I was doing the best I could at the time, even if it wasn't perfect. I was going through a lot myself, and I didn't always handle things the way I wish I had. But I never stopped loving my children, and I tried to be there for them as much as I could. I made mistakes, but I'm still their mother, and I'm still trying to be the best mother I can be, even now.

Therapist: That's a really powerful reframing of the situation, Maria. You're acknowledging the complexity of what you were going through, and the fact that you didn't always handle things perfectly, but you're also recognizing your ongoing love for your children and your efforts to be there for them. That's a much more balanced and compassionate view than the all-or-nothing belief that you failed as a mother.

This is a great example of how we can use cognitive restructuring to shift our perspective on a situation. By examining the evidence for and against our beliefs, and considering alternative viewpoints, we can develop a more balanced and realistic understanding.

How does it feel to view the situation in this new way? Does it have any impact on the feelings of guilt and shame you've been carrying?

Patient: It feels... lighter, I guess. Like I'm not carrying quite as much weight on my shoulders. I still feel sad about what happened, and I wish I could go back and do things differently, but I don't feel quite as much like a failure as I did before.

Therapist: That's really significant, Maria. Shifting our perspective can have a powerful impact on our emotions. It doesn't necessarily take away all the pain or regret, but it can help to ease the burden of guilt and shame.

As we continue to work on developing a more compassionate inner dialogue, I think you'll find that your feelings of guilt and shame will continue to lessen. It's a process, and it takes practice, but you're already making really important strides.

Before we move on, I want to check in with you about how you're feeling in this moment. This has been a pretty heavy discussion, and I want to make sure we're not pushing too far too fast. How are you feeling right now?

Patient: I'm feeling okay. It's a lot to process, but I feel like I'm starting to see things in a new way, which is good. I know I still have a lot of work to do, but I feel like I'm making progress.

Therapist: I'm really glad to hear that, Maria. It's okay to take things at your own pace, and we can always pause or come back to a topic if it feels like too much. I'm here to support you in whatever way works best for you.

Given what we've discussed today, I'm wondering if we might set a homework assignment related to this idea of developing a more compassionate inner dialogue. What do you think about trying to write another self-compassionate journal entry, but this time focusing on the progress you've made and the efforts you're continuing to make, rather than on your perceived failures or shortcomings?

Patient: That sounds like a good idea. I think it will be challenging, but I'm willing to try. I can see how important it is to start shifting my perspective and being kinder to myself.

Therapist: I think that's a great attitude to have, Maria. It's okay if it's challenging - that's to be expected. The important thing is that you're willing to try, and that you're open to the process of change.

Why don't we take a few minutes now to brainstorm some specific things you might include in your journal entry? I think it can be helpful to have a plan in place, so you feel more prepared when you sit down to write.

Patient: That would be really helpful. I always feel a bit stuck when I try to journal on my own, so having some ideas to start with would be great.

Therapist: Absolutely, let's do that. Given what we've talked about today, what are some things you might want to include in your journal entry?
